info.name: Equalum External
info.description:
# Introduction
Equalum is the industryâ€™s most scalable and comprehensive data ingestion platform, combining streaming Change Data Capture (CDC) with modern data transformation and bulk replication capabilities. Equalum also supports high scale batch processing and streaming ETL. 

The Equalum API exposes most of Equalum's functionality, including:
* The creation of Equalum objects - Sources, Targets, Replication Groups.
* The creation of flows - including the definition of flow pipelines using flow operators for data transformation and manipulation.
* Execution of flows - flow executions can be managed and run. 
* Viewing all objects - lists of all objects and their details.      

# API Reference Overview
Add information on how the API is integrated and enabled. 

# Authentication
Equalum API uses **Basic Authorization**. Basic authentication is a simple authentication scheme built into the HTTP protocol. The client sends HTTP requests with the Authorization header that contains the word Basic word followed by a space and a base64-encoded string username:password. For example, to authorize as demo / p@55w0rd the client would send:
``Authorization: Basic ZGVtbzpwQDU1dzByZA==``

# Error Codes
Equalum uses conventional HTTP response codes to indicate the success or failure of an API request. In general: Codes in the 2xx range indicate success. Codes in the 4xx range indicate an error that failed given the information provided (e.g., a required parameter was omitted, a charge failed, etc.). Codes in the 5xx range indicate an error with Equalum's servers (these are rare).

item.name: Source

request.description:
## list Sources API
Returns a list of previously created Sources with their details.
A Source is where the data is captured from by Equalum. 
Equalum can capture data from a wide variety of common enterprise source systems, including relational databases, NoSQL databases, files and logs, applications and message buses / APIs.

request.description:
## list Sources API
Returns a list of previously created Sources with their details.
A Source is where the data is captured from by Equalum. 
Equalum can capture data from a wide variety of common enterprise source systems, including relational databases, NoSQL databases, files and logs, applications and message buses / APIs.

request.description:
Returns the details of all the flow versions for the specified flow. 

Equalum features a version control mechanism for managing the flow design cycle. The flow versions include the following statuses: 
   * **Draft** â€“ this status is used when a new flow is being designed, but not yet published or when a published flow is being modified, before the changes are published. 
   * **Published** â€“ this status is associated with a flow version that has been published (using the Publish action). This means that this flow version is ready to be executed. There can be only one flow version with this status. If you want to publish a new draft, you will be prompted to either archive or delete the existing "Published" flow. 
   * **Archived** â€“ this is a historical flow version. An archived flow may still have in-progress batch executions linked to it, if these executions were submitted when the version had the Published status.

request.description:
Returns the details of all the flow versions for the specified flow. 

Equalum features a version control mechanism for managing the flow design cycle. The flow versions include the following statuses: 
   * **Draft** â€“ this status is used when a new flow is being designed, but not yet published or when a published flow is being modified, before the changes are published. 
   * **Published** â€“ this status is associated with a flow version that has been published (using the Publish action). This means that this flow version is ready to be executed. There can be only one flow version with this status. If you want to publish a new draft, you will be prompted to either archive or delete the existing "Published" flow. 
   * **Archived** â€“ this is a historical flow version. An archived flow may still have in-progress batch executions linked to it, if these executions were submitted when the version had the Published status.

item.description:
A Flow in Equalum determines the processing that Equalum will perform on the data while it is streamed to its target. This processing includes a wide variety of data manipulations and enrichment operations. 

Equalum features a version control mechanism for managing the flow design cycle. The flow versions include the following statuses: 
   * **Draft** â€“ this status is used when a new flow is being designed, but not yet published or when a published flow is being modified, before the changes are published. 
   * **Published** â€“ this status is associated with a flow version that has been published (using the Publish action). This means that this flow version is ready to be executed. There can be only one flow version with this status. If you want to publish a new draft, you will be prompted to either archive or delete the existing "Published" flow. 
   * **Archived** â€“ this is a historical flow version. An archived flow may still have in-progress batch executions linked to it, if these executions were submitted when the version had the Published status.

item.description:
A Flow Execution details the processing of a flow by Equalum. When the flow version is "Published" it is ready to be executed. 
There are two types of executions:
   * **Streaming executions** â€“ a streaming execution represents a continuous processing of an input. The execution only ends when the user explicitly stops it (e.g. when the user asks it to be canceled, deletes its version, execute a new version, etc.) or when it can no longer perform continuous processing (e.g. when the user asks it to start over from a different position). This type of execution is typically performed on data that is constantly being produced/streamed, as opposed to existing data that was already produced in the past. 
   * **Batch executions** - a batch execution processes all its inputs in one batch (not incrementally) and then stops. This execution runs over a specific input, that is defined at batch submission time. This type of execution is typically performed on data that has been already produced in the past.
